Title.evidence: Background: Local excision (LE) after chemoradiotherapy is a new option in low rectal cancer, but morbidity has never been compared prospectively with total mesorectal excision (TME).

Trial_Design.evidence: Method: This was a post-hoc analysis from a randomized trial.

Participants.evidence: Patients with clinical T2/T3 low rectal cancer with good response to the chemoradiotherapy and having either LE, LE with eventual completion TME, or TME were considered.

Intervention.evidence: Early and late morbidity were compared in patients treated either by LE or TME after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy for rectal cancer.

Objective.evidence: Early and late morbidity were compared in patients treated either by LE or TME after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy for rectal cancer.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Early (1 month) and late (2 years) morbidities were compared between the three groups.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Method: This was a post-hoc analysis from a randomized trial.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Early surgical morbidity (20 per cent LE versus 36 per cent TME versus 43 per cent completion TME, P = 0.025) and late surgical morbidity (4 per cent versus 33 per cent versus 57 per cent, P < 0.001) were significantly lower in the LE group than in the TME or the completion TME group.

Harms.evidence: There were no deaths following surgery in any of the three groups.
